```{r mapping-submerged-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_submerged_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_submerged_token)
mapping_submerged_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'submerged') %>% left_join(mapping_submerged_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_submerged_token_stats)
submerged_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("submerged", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

This is a generic, [motion]{.smallcaps}-based metaphor capturing the way anger metaphorically exist and it is not attested in the type-based dataset. This is slightly different from the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor ([Section \@ref(unveiled-tokenbased)](#unveiled-tokenbased)) where anger already exists and that highlights the issue of whether the experiencer is keen to show/unveil the anger to others or not (i.e., hiding it) [cf. @rajeg_metaphorical_2019, 158]. Compared to the other metaphors discussed so far, [anger is submerged entity]{.smallcaps} is rather conventionalised in its linguistic realisation, given it is manifested by small number of types (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_type', 'submerged')`) making up the high token of the metaphor (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_token', 'submerged')`); that is, only `r get_meta_freq_profiles('submerged', type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor_tokenbased, metaphor_var = "cm_broader")[[2]]`% of the metaphor's token are of different types that are repeated many times.

The key mapping is `r get_key_mappings(mapping_submerged_token)`. From this mapping, two entailed mappings are postulated based on the semantics of the source-domain frame lexical units.

- experiencing anger is the presence/emergence/protruding of the entity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_submerged_token_stats, "protruding")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_submerged_token, "protruding", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_submerged_token, "protruding")`

- causing anger is forcing the entity to emerge (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_submerged_token_stats, "to emerge")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_submerged_token, "to emerge", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_submerged_token, "to emerge")`


### [Anger is sleeping organism]{.smallcaps} {#sleeping-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-sleeping-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_sleeping_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "sleeping")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_sleeping_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_sleeping_token)
mapping_sleeping_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'sleeping') %>% left_join(mapping_sleeping_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_sleeping_token_stats)
sleeping_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("sleeping", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

The [sleeping organism]{.smallcaps} metaphor, also attested in the type-based dataset in the lower rank (i.e. `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, "sleeping")`) ([Section \@ref(awakening-typebased)](#awakening-typebased)), is based on the [awakening]{.smallcaps} frame in the MN repository in combination with the [caused upward motion]{.smallcaps} frame. The utilised aspect of the source frame is to cause the inactive and calm organism to become active/alert (e.g., being awake and aroused), or to indicate the active/awaken state of the organism. The manner of the awakening/alerting can be fishing for the organism via bait. In the target frame of [anger]{.smallcaps}, this is mapped onto the causal aspect for the presence of anger. This metaphor could be considered as a pre-condition for the existing danger and fierceness of the organism (i.e., anger) that need to be restrained as highlighted in the [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphor ([Section \@ref(animal-tokenbased)](#animal-tokenbased)). The [sleeping organism]{.smallcaps} metaphor is proposed in Stefanowitsch's [-@stefanowitsch_words_2006, 76-77] corpus study on [anger]{.smallcaps} in British English. 

Key mapping: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_sleeping_token)`

- causing anger is fishing/awakening the calm entity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_sleeping_token_stats, "awakening")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_sleeping_token, "awakening", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_sleeping_token, "awakening")`

- anger near the limit is awaken/alerted entity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_sleeping_token_stats, "alerted")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_sleeping_token, "alerted", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_sleeping_token, "alerted")`


Like the [submerged entity]{.smallcaps}, the [sleeping organism]{.smallcaps} highlights the way anger is brought about, but utilising a different image, namely alerting or awakening an inactive organism. The conventionalised lexical unit of this metaphor is based on the root *pancing* 'lure a fish using a bite; to fish for sth.' and *bangkit* 'wake/get up'. Example (@bangunkan_macan) in [Section \@ref(awakening-typebased)](#awakening-typebased) has shown that this metaphor motivates a common proverb for anger in Indonesian that relates to awakening a sleeping tiger.

### [Anger is natural force]{.smallcaps} {#naturalforce-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-naturalforce-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_naturalforce_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "natural force")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_naturalforce_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_naturalforce_token)
mapping_naturalforce_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'natural force') %>% left_join(mapping_naturalforce_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats)
naturalforce_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("natural force", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

The metaphor occupies nearly similar rank in the two datasets (i.e., `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, "natural")` in the type-based dataset and `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, "natural")` in the token-based one). This metaphor is predominantly composed of metaphorical patterns evoking frames within the [harm]{.smallcaps} family, particularly sub-cases of the [destroying]{.smallcaps} frame, namely [natural disaster]{.smallcaps} (type=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'natural disaster')), type)`; token=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'natural disaster')), n)`) and [destructive natural process]{.smallcaps} (type=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'destructive')), type)`; token=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'destructive')), n)`). The other minor source frames are [non-translational motion]{.smallcaps} (type=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'translational')), type)`; token=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'translational')), n)`) and [weather]{.smallcaps} (type=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'weather')), type)`; token=`r pull(filter(naturalforce_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'weather')), n)`). Together, the metaphorical patterns of these frames evoke `r happyr::numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_mapping", 'natural'))` mappings.

Key mapping(s): `r get_key_mappings(mapping_naturalforce_token)`

- degree of effect is amount of destructive force (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats, "degree of effect")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_naturalforce_token, "degree of effect", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_naturalforce_token, "degree of effect")`

- experiencing anger is being destroyed (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats, "being destroyed")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_naturalforce_token, "being destroyed", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_naturalforce_token, "being destroyed")`

- causing anger to cease is reducing the amount of the disaster (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats, "reducing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_naturalforce_token, "reducing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_naturalforce_token, "reducing")`

- ceasing anger is ceasing amount of force (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats, "ceasing anger")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_naturalforce_token, "ceasing anger", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_naturalforce_token, "ceasing anger")`
  
The [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphor mainly focuses on the intensity of the effect of the natural force, as evident by the productivity of this mapping. This is a more specific and different way of construing harmful effect of anger than the other [harm]{.smallcaps}-related metaphor based on different frames within the same family ([Section \@ref(harm-tokenbased)](#harm-tokenbased)).



### [Anger is subjugator]{.smallcaps} {#subjugator-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-subjugator-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_subjugator_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "subjugator")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_subjugator_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_subjugator_token)
mapping_subjugator_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'subjugator') %>% left_join(mapping_subjugator_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_subjugator_token_stats)
subjugator_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("subjugator", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

The [subjugator]{.smallcaps} metaphor is mainly based on the correspondence between anger and the Subjugator frame-role in the MN [servitude]{.smallcaps} frame. It is an alias to the [social superior]{.smallcaps} or [social force]{.smallcaps} metaphors proposed in the literature [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 21, 70]. Kvecses [-@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 71] argues that this metaphor involves asymmetric control-relation between the social inferior (the Subjugated role in the [servitude]{.smallcaps} frame), namely the emoter/self (or its associates), and the social superior (Subjugator), namely the emotion itself. The authority element is incorporated into the [servitude]{.smallcaps} frame from the structure of the MN [authority]{.smallcaps} frame, which in turn is the sub-case of the [control]{.smallcaps} frame. There are `r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, col_names = 'n_mapping', 'subjugator')` mappings in this metaphor, evoked by `r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, col_names = 'n_type', 'subjugator')` types for the total `r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, col_names = 'n_token', 'subjugator')` tokens.

Key mapping(s): `r get_key_mappings(mapping_subjugator_token)`

- effect of and losing control over anger is being subjugated (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_subjugator_token_stats, "being subjugated")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_subjugator_token, "being subjugated", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_subjugator_token, "being subjugated")`

- managing anger is exercise domination over the subjugator (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_subjugator_token_stats, "domination")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_subjugator_token, "domination", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_subjugator_token, "domination")`

- angry person is inferior object of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_subjugator_token_stats, "inferior object")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_subjugator_token, "inferior object", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_subjugator_token, "inferior object")`

The type-based dataset does not reveal the use of this metaphor for [anger]{.smallcaps}. The main meaning focus of this metaphor is on the emotional effect of anger (e.g., being irrational), which is construed via the degree of control and power the authority has over the subjugated. This focus is manifested as the predominant mapping in the metaphor. There is only a small number of types that evoke the self's attempt to manage anger (i.e., exercise/compromising control).

```{r mapping-biological-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_biological_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "biological entity")) %>%

biological_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("biological entity", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

The [biological entity]{.smallcaps} metaphor has relatively low tokens (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_token", "biological")`) and sits pretty low in the top-20 salience metaphor (rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'biological')`). However, it is expressed by relatively varied metaphorical patterns (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_type", "biological")` types out of `r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_token", "biological")` tokens) and elaborate mappings (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_mapping", "biological")`). The followings are mappings postulated from the metaphorical patterns. 

- anger leading to other effects is the root/base/seed of an organism from which sth. grows (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "root\\/base\\/seed")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "root\\/base\\/seed", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "root\\/base\\/seed")`
  
- anger as a consequence of an event is fruits/yields of a plant (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "fruits\\/yields")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "fruits\\/yields", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "fruits\\/yields")`

- cause of anger is the seed/source of an organism (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "seed\\/source")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "seed\\/source", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "seed\\/source")`

- the presence of anger is the growth/birth of the organism (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "growth\\/birth")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "growth\\/birth", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "growth\\/birth")`

- effect of anger is plants creeping out (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "creeping out")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "creeping out", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "creeping out")`

- maintaining anger is fertilising the organism/plant (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "fertilising")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "fertilising", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "fertilising")`

As can be seen, no single mapping could be singled out as predominant. The metaphorical patterns utilise different components of the structure of the [organism]{.smallcaps} frame family (e.g., [plant life cycle]{.smallcaps} and [animate entity]{.smallcaps}) to highlight different aspects of [anger]{.smallcaps}. For instance, [anger]{.smallcaps} can be considered as a consequence of an event, or as a cause leading to another effect. The metaphor also includes patterns referring to the cause, existence, and effect of [anger]{.smallcaps}.


### [Anger is (un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} {#unveiled-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-hidden-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_hidden_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "veiled object")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_hidden_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_hidden_token)
mapping_hidden_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'veiled object') %>% left_join(mapping_hidden_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_hidden_token_stats)
hidden_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("veiled object", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```


This metaphor is attested in the two datasets and occupies the lower rank in the top-20 tables (rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'veiled')` in the token-based dataset, and rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'veiled')` in the type-based one). In this metaphor, [anger]{.smallcaps} is construed as an object that the experiencer has control over in order to be either displayed (i.e., expressed for others to perceive), or keep it hidden, hence perceptually inaccessible by others. These two inferences, which are re-cast as the mappings in the metaphor, are based on the [hiding]{.smallcaps} and [cause to see]{.smallcaps} frames evoked by the metaphorical patterns.

Key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_hidden_token)`

- expressing anger is unveiling an object (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hidden_token_stats, "expressing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hidden_token, "expressing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hidden_token, "expressing")`

- suppressing anger is hiding/protecting an object (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hidden_token_stats, "suppressing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hidden_token, "suppressing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hidden_token, "suppressing")`


The main focus of this metaphor in the token-based dataset is on the externalisation or "unveiling" the anger as shown by the higher type and token frequencies of this mapping compared to the hiding of the object mapping. In contrast, in the type-based dataset ([Section \@ref(hidden-typebased)](#hidden-typebased)) it is the mapping referring to the suppression of anger (i.e., maintaining control by "hiding" the object) that is predominant. Overall, the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor highlights the issue of control and expression of [anger]{.smallcaps}.


### [Anger is physical contact/harm]{.smallcaps} {#harm-tokenbased}

The metaphor is a sub-case of the [emotional effect is physical contact]{.smallcaps} metaphor proposed by Lakoff and Johnson [@lakoff_metaphors_1980, 50]. It is part of the [force-dynamic]{.smallcaps} system of emotion metaphor [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 83-85]. The metaphorical patterns evoke the [physical harm]{.smallcaps} frame capture the effect of [anger]{.smallcaps} as impacting both the experiencer and other entities that become the target of angry person, especially when the harmed entity role of the frame is filled with entity other than the experiencer of anger. The following are mappings postulated from the metaphor.

```{r mapping-harm-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_harm_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "harm$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_harm_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_harm_token)
mapping_harm_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'harm$') %>% left_join(mapping_harm_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_harm_token_stats)
harm_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("harm$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

Key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_harm_token)`

- effect of anger is harmful effect (at others) (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_harm_token_stats, "harmful effect")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_harm_token, "harmful effect", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_harm_token, "harmful effect")`

- experiencing anger is physical harm (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_harm_token_stats, "experiencing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_harm_token, "experiencing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_harm_token, "experiencing")`


In Kvecses's [-@kovecses_metaphor_2000] [force-dynamic]{.smallcaps} system, the metaphor highlight predominantly the part where the experience of anger leads to experiencer's responses (e.g., directing the harm at others). This highlighted aspect is also an important part of the [anger is natural force]{.smallcaps}, [anger is subjugator]{.smallcaps}, and [anger is weapon]{.smallcaps} metaphor.

The [contact/harm]{.smallcaps} metaphor is also attested in the type-based dataset and ranks in the top-3 of the type-based salience table ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-type-based)](#metaphor-table-type-based)), unlike in the token-based salience table. An interesting difference is that in the type-based dataset, the predominant types focuses the cause of anger. The expressions referring to physical touching or harm are used in the context of harming the candidate experiencer (i.e., causing the candidate experiencer to be angry) ([Section \@ref(harm-typebased)](#harm-typebased)). In the token-based dataset, however, the physical harm expressions are used in the context of showing the harmful effect when experiencing anger and when targeting that effect to others.

### [Intensity is luminousity]{.smallcaps} {#luminousity-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-luminousity-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_luminousity_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "luminousity$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_luminousity_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_luminousity_token)
mapping_luminousity_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'luminousity$') %>% left_join(mapping_luminousity_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_luminousity_token_stats)
luminousity_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("luminousity$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

In the bottom five of the top-20 token-based metaphors ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-token-based)](#metaphor-table-token-based)), [intensity is luminousity]{.smallcaps} has the highest token (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_token', 'luminousity$')`) but also the lowest types (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_type', 'luminousity$')`) and mappings (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_mapping', 'luminousity$')`). Moreover, the metaphor is not attested in the type-based dataset. These are the metaphorical mappings.

The key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_luminousity_token)`

- reducing anger is reducing the level of light (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_luminousity_token_stats, "reducing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_luminousity_token, "reducing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_luminousity_token, "reducing")`

The metaphor is based on lexical units evoking the [darkness]{.smallcaps} frame in MN, a perspective of the [luminosity]{.smallcaps} frame that characterises the amount of light from a light source. The frames are utilised in highlighting the ceasing intensity of anger. In this way, [intensity is luminousity]{.smallcaps} is related to the [anger is fire]{.smallcaps} ([Section \@ref(fire-tokenbased)](#fire-tokenbased)) but captures anger's intensity not via the degree of heat of fire, but via the amount of light.

### [Anger is person]{.smallcaps} {#person-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-person-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_person_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "person$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_person_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_person_token)
mapping_person_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'person$') %>% left_join(mapping_person_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_person_token_stats)
person_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("person$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

This metaphor could be considered as a soft personification of [anger]{.smallcaps}. Unlike the other personifying metaphors, such as [adversary]{.smallcaps} or [subjugator]{.smallcaps}, [anger is person]{.smallcaps} captures the causation and diminishing of anger, rather than the intensity and effect of it (see the mappings below). It is based on lexical units that evoke features of the MN [person]{.smallcaps} frame, which is a sub-case of the [animate entity]{.smallcaps} and [sentient]{.smallcaps} frames. 

Key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_person_token)`

- causing anger is inviting a person to come (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "inviting")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "inviting", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "inviting")`

- experiencing anger is being friend with/welcome by a person (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "friend")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "friend", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "friend")`

- reducing anger is dismissing the invited person (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "dismissing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "dismissing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "dismissing")`

The metaphorical patterns refer to actions and objectives that animate as well as sentient/cognising entities such as a person typically do. These includes welcoming, inviting, dismissing, and befriend or playing with someone. In a way, such actions represent anger as a superficially safe emotion to be with.

## Metonymy {#tokenbased-metonymy-salience-results}

```{r metonymy-category-tokenbased}
physiological_response_regex <- "(body heat|internal pressure|redness|breathing|visual interference|body hair|teeth biting|foaming|speechless)"
metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience %>% 
  mutate(category = if_else(str_detect(METONYMY, physiological_response_regex), "physiological response", "social-communicative behaviour"))

physiology_type <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category %>% 
  filter(category == "physiological response") %>% 
  mutate(meto_stats = paste("[", METONYMY, "]{.smallcaps} (type=", n_type, "; token=", n_token, ")", sep = "")) %>% 
  pull(meto_stats)
physiology_type_total <- paste("*TOTAL~type~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type),"*; *TOTAL~token~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token), "*", sep = "")
physiology_type <- c(physiology_type, physiology_type_total)

social_type <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category %>% 
  filter(category != "physiological response") %>% 
  mutate(meto_stats = paste("[", METONYMY, "]{.smallcaps} (type=", n_type, "; token=", n_token, ")", sep = "")) %>% 
  pull(meto_stats)
social_type_total <- paste("*TOTAL~type~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type),"*; *TOTAL~token~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), "*", sep = "")
social_type <- c(social_type, rep("", 3), social_type_total)

metonymy_tokenbased_category_print <- tibble(`social-communicative behaviour:` = social_type, `physiological response:` = physiology_type)
```

### Types of the metonymies (token-based dataset) {#metonymy-category-tokenbased}

From `r nrow(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category)` metonymies, `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response"))` metonymies represent physiological responses (type=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type)`; token=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token)`), and `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response"))` are of the social-communicative behaviour types (type=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type)`; token=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token)`).

```{r metonymy-category-table-tokenbased}
metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_type <- binom.test(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type), sum(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type), sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type)))

metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_token <- binom.test(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), sum(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token)))

metonymy_tokenbased_category_print %>% knitr::kable(caption = "Two types of metonymies of [anger]{.smallcaps} (token-based dataset)")
```

As in the type-based dataset ([Section \@ref(metonymy-category-typebased)](#metonymy-category-typebased)), the number of metonymies in the physiological response category are greater than the ones in the social-communicative behaviour. However, the social-communicative behaviour category in total still exhibits significantly greater number of types (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_type$p.value)`) and tokens (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_token$p.value)`) than the physiological response category. So the type-based and token-based datasets converge along these distributional aspects of the metonymies.
